title: Footage shows moment gang stole £250,000 by ripping out cash machines from shops
text:

Worrying footage has shown the moment a "ruthless" gang of criminals stole £250,000 by ripping out a series of public cash machines in broad daylight.

The thieves tied cargo straps around 11 freestanding ATMs before pulling them out using vehicles with cloned number plates - or wheeling them out to getaway cars on trollies.

The machines, fitted in shops - and even a hospital - were broken into between March 2018 and January this year.

Five members of the gang were jailed for more than 31 years at Birmingham Crown Court on Tuesday after they admitted conspiracy to commit commercial burglary.

Judge Heidi Kubic described their crimes as “sophisticated burglaries” which left a trail of destruction across the West Midlands.

Craig Matthews, 42, of Edgbaston, Birmingham, was jailed for eight years and seven months.

(Image: SWNS)

(Image: SWNS)

(Image: SWNS)

David Bradley, 28, of Coventry, was jailed for five years while Bourne, 38, of Fillongley, Warks., was sentenced to six years.

Shane Stajsavljevic (corr), 36, of Coventry, was jailed for seven years and two months and Charlie Ward, 27, also of Coventry, was caged for five years.

The court heard on March 15 last year, the gang used cutting equipment to break into a Spar supermarket in Tamworth, Staffs., before ripping out the cash machine.

On September 24, they cut bollards to get into Birmingham’s Cannon Hill Park, where they dragged a cash machine from the Midlands Arts Centre.

Five days later on September 29, they destroyed the inside of a Post Office in Lichfield to drag the cash machine through it after taping over CCTV cameras.

(Image: SWNS)

(Image: SWNS)

On October 17, they went into Birmingham’s Queen Elizabeth Hospital before loading an ATM onto a trolley and walking out, past members of the public.

On January 27 this year, security guards had to dodge out of the way of their van after they were disturbed at a cash and carry in Birmingham.

West Midlands Police used CCTV, forensics and phone analysis to catch the criminals, particularly once they were forced to abandon a getaway Transit van.

Fingerprints left on a trolley they had dumped at one crime scene helped detectives identify their faces.

Ringleader Craig Matthews, who has 19 previous convictions spanning 49 offences, left his DNA on a piece of tape used to cover cameras in Lichfield.

He was also forensically linked to a registration plate on one of the vans.

Police uncovered CCTV of him examining a cash machine while unsuspecting passengers went about their business at Rugby train station.

They were arrested at the beginning of this year and went on to admit conspiracy to commit commercial burglary.

Detective Chief Inspector Annie Miller said: “This was sophisticated organised crime which showed a huge amount of planning.

“While no one was hurt during the spree, the gang left a trail of destruction which left victims facing huge bills.

“Thanks to great police work, we were able to build up a detailed picture of the gang, their vehicles, reconnaissance and movements.

“We’re continuing to work with the cash machine industry to help increase security to reduce the risk of them being targeted by criminals in this way in the future."

The industry has launched a drive called Secure ATM, including sprays that identify thieves for up to five years after an attack, dyes that are sprayed on cash and kits which neutralised gas used to blow up machines.
description: The five of them targeted 11 machines in under a year but were eventually caught and today jailed for a total of over 31 years
